												This is such an underrated game.  The characters are what really sold me on this game.  Unlike other series in which you play as "bad guys" who ultimately tend to do the right thing, Kane and Lynch are 100% scumbags.  Kane is a self-serving, traitorous sociopath and Lynch is just completely mental.  It's a real treat to see how they interact with each other and how their personalities affect the storyline. The combat is good, not great.  The cover system is a little wonky and the AI is outright terrible at times, but I was always having enough fun that these issues didn't bother me much.  Shooting feels off at first, but as you progress and get a feel for the weapons, it becomes a total joy.  You really get the feel of desperation that would accompany a heist gone wrong leading into a frantic shootout with the cops (like I would know).  Kudos to whoever did the sound for the weapons, I haven't heard beefier sounding assault rifles in any other game!The graphics are pretty mediocre, and look like what you'd expect from a non triple-A title in 2007.  That being said, the levels you play in are more than interesting enough to make up for it.  You'll go from banks and upscale office buildings to the streets and rooftops of Tokyo to Havana in the middle of a political revolution.  One of my favorite set pieces was a gunfight in a busy nightclub, which seemed to be lifted straight out of the movie "Collateral."Overall, this is a solid game with a few flaws that stand out, but definitely won't ruin the experience of playing as such interesting characters in such interesting situations.  And for only $6.99 (down from $60 when it came out) you can't go wrong giving it a try!

Essentially a third-person shooter with some simple squad commands, it is an uninspired, frustrating action experience. For example, to jump into cover, you simply run up to an obstacle. Sounds easy enough, except you have to run into a wall or obstacle a couple times before you "click" into cover.Targeting is just as irritating. Gunshots seem a hair off almost every time. Computer-controlled players prefer to play hide-and-seek rather than to engage in heated battles. Kane & Lynch showed promise with a strong story, but after a few levels it turns up dead on arrival. Overall, however, the game is an enjoyable piece of software that will keep you entertained in its sub-par length game of approx. 5 hours.

												Kane & Lynch is certainly a controversial one. Famously responsible for getting Gamespot employee Jeff Gerstman fired, Kane & Lynch has earned a reputation for being a game that whilst being promising given the developer background (I.e Hitman series) ultimately led to dissapointment. However is this lukewarm reception justified? In a way, it sort of is. The story is your standard revenge tale following main leads Kane and Lynch as Kane attempts to get his daughter back from an old gang that wants him dead. Nothing hugely inventive and with no real twists or turns in the plot it remains pretty uninteresting save for the ending which just happens upruptly and really leaves you with a feeling of "Is that it?". The most intreguing part of this story are its characters. Whilst Kane and Lynch themselves aren't hugely dimensional, the fact that they are often portrayed as bad people brings a nice, not often explored angle to the entire game. This portrayl lends itself well within the first half of the game with many heist like activites being the main goal, such things as bank heists, nightclub areas and prison breakouts. These areas prove to be where the game shows off the potential it could have had if more love and care went into the entire package.The gameplay itself isn't all that exciting, just your standard third person action shooter affair. However the cover system isn't traditionally placed on a button in Kane & Lynch, instead they opted to make it an automatic cover system so you instantly stick to a wall. This sounds good in theory and for the first half of the game it works ok but it's in the game's second half where it falls apart. The problem is that the system doesn't work half the time leaving you running at the wall like a fool hoping you'll stick to it, this led to a small number of deaths that could have been easily avoided if the cover system was more competant. Also your partner AI is seriously dumb in most instances often getting themselves downed in need of saving because they stood out in enemy fire which again leads to numerous game overs.The game's presentation is sloppy at best; pretty bad lip syncing in game, dialogue interupting other dialogue which causes them to over lap, bland visuals and design. That said however the voicework itself is pretty decent and varies up the locations to at least give some semblance of variety. Overall Kane & Lynch isn't going to set the world on fire or win any awards, however it doesn't totally fail as there is some fun to be had with the servicable shooting. If you see it for sale at around £5 then it's probably worth the 3-4 hours of gameplay, just don't expect it to be all that great.

												As the Eidos publicity machine readied itself to push its new shooter, the two lead characters that emerged as the stars of IO Entertainment's gruesome crime caper presented themselves as some of the most irreverent in gaming's history. The pair that make up Kane & Lynch may sound like a duo from a buddy movie where two rule-bending cops save the day, but they are in fact deeply disturbed convicts, broken out of prison by balaclava-clad henchmen, so they may repay a debt to a mysterious crime organisation.You assume the role of Kane; a monstrous killer with a good man trapped inside of him, who has had his wife and child kidnapped while he is serving time, meaning he must jump to the fiddle of a group called The Seven, who will destroy the remnants of his family life without blinking. Kane is consumed by rage and sadness, but has a touch of Max Payne about him. He has almost nothing to lose, and will stop at nothing to get to his wife and daughter, and it's hard not to warm to him even though he is a dangerous killer.Lynch is your side kick; a violent maniac who's psychological profile would likely read like there had been a serious administrative error in a psychiatrist's filing cabinet.He is prone to attacks of intense hallucinations, that usually stir him into a trigger-happy frenzy where innocent bystanders are fair game, and is sent to watch over you as you struggle to return a mysterious bounty to The Seven. With such intriguing and powerful characters it's easy to get swept in by Kane & Lynch: Dead Men, but after several hours of play, it is going to be the gameplay that really matters.In that regard, Dead Men is of mixed success.There are times when the best technique is to charge head on with scant regard for accurate aiming, fighting with fists and shooting from the hip. Then, a moment later you're expected to work your way forward methodically, picking enemies off from quite a distance. While variety is desperately needed in most shooters, here it is too sporadic, and often hopping between the two is rather confusing.There's also the fact that the targeting reticule blends into the background with infuriating ease, and the tendency of weapons to spread their ammunitions means while they are great for close exchanges of fire, missions with an emphasis on ranged shooting can be incredibly annoying. In every game mode snapping on to cover is unreliable, and the basic controls for climbing never seem to work particularly well. For every staggering set piece there is a niggling problem, and it means that while we all wanted Kane & Lynch to be near perfect, it is instead ever so slightly flawed. The visuals are as mixed as the rest of the game. Sometimes stylish and detailed, Kane & Lynch can also come across as rather rough and untidy.If you enjoy games with decent plots, developed characters and decent dialogue, this violent, offensive and witty action game is probably worth your attention, and if you're a shooting game purist, try not to expect too much.

It was not bad among other shooters 10 years back, but, after the time passed, it's not worth to actually play it anymore.Let's forget about compatibility issues (GFWL isn't working, but that's no big deal anymore, just a game without achievements and multiplayer). Even the music (performed by Jasper Kid, if that rings any bells) isn't good and thrilling anymore.All the cool level setups, borrowed from such Michael Mann's movies as "the Heat" or "Collateral", are no so great - since they were copied too many times, and since they're not original in the first place.The story of betrayal, where betrayed betrays betrayer, and betrayer straighten things up by more betrayals... Well, it sounds stupid, but it still sounds better than it actually is in the game.Note that Kane and Lynch isn't a bad game because it's about bad men. No, it's just a very mediocre shooter, which was lame and secondary-made from the start, and aged very badly. With all those tech troubles... Now it's just doesn't worth the hassle. If you want shootouts - look for GTA great heists, or the Payday 2 - they do all that what was good in the K&L much better.So, my mark is 6/10. Game was worth a one go through in the time it was new. Now, it's better to stay away - unless you have some nostalgia troubles, which I doubt. Try a Youtube walkthrough, maybe? And remember, the shooting, especially aiming, is really bad there.

												I'm not going to pretend that this game is perfect.  Read enough of the other reviews and you will clearly see that people are mixed on this game.  I'm also not going to touch on the review scandal.  That was an ugly bit of business, but it doesn't impact the game on its own merits.  It showcases how scummy the company is that made the game.  I like the characters overall.  The gang of mercs that you build up has their own personalities and each one adds to the story a little bit, but the center is on Kane and Lynch.  The banter between these 2 during the course of a mission can be a lot of fun to listen to and it helps drive the story a little bit further.  Games like this usually don't have much of a story to them, but this one has little pockets waiting to be seen, if you give it a chance.  It's not without issues, though.  The cover system, while functional at times, does not always work and sometimes you will snap into cover at odd angles or stupid moments and it won't work when you always need it to.  Gunfire definitely drives your aim skyward, but that is a relaistic idea (even if it seems too aggressive in this game).  Enemies do take a fair number of hits to put them down, but if you're in that much of a bad situation, you can always switch to your pistol and go for headshots.  The music and sound effects are great and, again, the banter between the characters will keep things moving.  Sure, profanity abounds in this, but given the source material, what did you expect?  Overall, a mix of locations (and the club shows how many people you can put on a screen at one time... nice chaotic atmosphere that makes it harder to get by without killing any innocents) keeps things interesting and varied.  There aren't too many guns, but there are enough to get the job done and give you a little freedom to determine what works best for you.Is it perfect?  Hell no.  Will you get frustrated with the things that don't work well?  Quite possibly.  But is it worth giving it a try to enjoy what does work?  Yes, I think it is.

												Prior to my purchase of Kane & Lynch: Dead Men, I had read, heard, and seen entirely mixed reviews on it. I'd been hesitant to buy it for this reason, however having now picked it up during a sale (a whopping $1.75) I was able to try it out. Having ran through the surprisingly short campaign (it took me four hours to complete, all within a single sitting, on the highest difficulty setting), I know understand why the game was so ill recieved by some. K&L:DM is a bog standard cover based third-person shooter in its gameplay, and that gameplay is subpar at best. Most weapons I found to be completely inaccurate at anything beyond short range, enemies were basically bullet sponges (however this may be attributed to the difficulty I was playing on), the movement was clunky, and attempting to get behind cover often resulted in either awkwardly walking against a wall, or sticking to cover that you didn't mean to stick to. Your AI teammates also seemed to be pretty dim as well. This, at points, lead to very frustrating moments, and many undeserved deaths. It's still functional, but it isn't sharp by any means. Where the game does shine however is in its narrative and atmosphere. The entire game felt grimey, from the characters to the enviroment and even the soundtrack. It nailed the "criminal" feeling quite well. The story was also quite good, although nothing I haven't seen before. Interesting (if a bit shallow) characters, and funny dialogue with more cuss words than a bar full of sailors propelled it forward. If you're willing to slog through the sketchy mechanics, then there's a good afternoons time to be had with this game. Though do as I did, and pick it up on sale. From the L.A Bank heist shootout to the Nightclub showdown, you’ll have a vague idea what rests ahead.Visually, the Hitman: Blood Money game engine has dated well. And holds up to many games this current generation with well-rounded reflections, shadows and environmental destruction which add a sense of realism and immersion into the game world. Cut scenes suffer from audio cutting out resulting in the end of the conversations missing, while the addition of sub-titles makes this issue smaller, the end result is a still mildly frustrating. Although it can get repetitive at times, there’s no stop sign to show at you by the constant number of henchmen coming at you. The command system that plays out in a strategic way where you can command your team mates/NPC’s to target selected enemies or take cover; however it was an under-exploited system because you will find yourself doing all the shooting due to the poor AI.Kane & Lynch is a thrilling but very violent and masochistic action game. You have the opportunity to end the lives of innocent bystanders to even hearing the voice of a cop beg for their life because they have children; all while the wife and daughter of Kane are held captive. The story follows at a psychological drama emotional vibe, and certain strong elements that would put the player in enough stress if it isn't by the story's way of destroying up the characters’ lives, and although it doesn't grab enough interest on its character development it does at least satisfy you with those individual personalities of each that makes a credible duo that are not precisely role models nor does it glamourize the lifestyle of the protagonist which many games or movies lean towards to justify their actions.Exciting, ultra-violent, masochistic guilt, pulse pounding vengeance, searing vulgarity and Japanese gangsters in leather motorcycle outfits, this game has every top-notch action film element one could ask for.

												On one hand you have Kane. He's calm, collected, has his stuff in order, but nothing ever seems to go his way. On the other hand, you have Lynch. He's psychotic and prone to being a complete screw-up, but at least he's consistent. This dynamic duo is out to do what they do best, kill a ton of people, and...and...and? There's a plot to this madness, but expect it to kinda fall by the wayside after the first hour and a half. It's clear to me that IO interactive had some great ideas, but they forgot to put it all together for most of the game. There's a prison bus escape, then some shoot-outs, there's a robbery, and then some more shoot-outs. The rest of the game takes place in Havana and Venezuela, and it plays out like every other 3rd person War game. To add to this, the PC port of this game is a bit crap. It's prone to glitches, poor graphic effects, and objects disappearing whenever they feel like it. I honestly thought they added to the game. It made for a very surreal atmosphere. It's possible that I don't find the game nearly as appealing as the characters. A lot of the time with these 3rd person shooters, you have Nathan "Indy" Drake, Lara "Rambo" Croft, the men (and women) of Gears of War, and so on. These heroes are made to be charismatic, given aspects that people can relate to, and are basically good people caught in bad situations. I mean okay, I can buy it sometimes, but the idea of playing as a couple horrible ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who make bad situations even worse? That's so cool. Would they be better off dead? Most definitely. However, I get the feeling that Hell wouldn't be an acceptable end for them. Hell is more like....stage 3. Somehow they shoot their way out, but manage to end up somewhere else, and shoot that place up as well. Along the way there would be a failed string of negotiations, heists, kidnappings, liberations, bar mitzvahs, and house parties. As a shooter, Dead Men is merely competent. Aside from the odd difficulty spike or two towards the end and some primo snipers, most gamers will sleepwalk through the chaos. Mostly this game gets by on some neats moments, its engaging protagonists, and some really decent sound-direction(good music). If you're curious and don't mind putting up with more issues than Sports Illustrated, give this game a go. During sales it tends to cost about as much as a candy bar, and lasts slightly longer.

												Quick Summary: Play an anti-hero like a poor man’s Max Payne in a third person shooter with a gritty semi-realistic storyline.  The game appears to have co-op functionality, but I don’t think you can go through the single player campaign with a friend. Also, the game uses Games for Windows Live.You play the campaign as Kane, a former mercenary indebted to a powerful crime group with international dealings. By indebted, I mean they own you and will kill your family if you don’t pay them back what you owe. The group has tasked Lynch, a low level thug as your new partner, and he’ll be tagging along with you to make sure you behave. Unfortunately Lynch has some serious problems, which add considerably to your own situation. The game is played as a third person shooter where you can pick up the weapons your fallen enemies drop, and/or request ammo from one of your allies (usually Lynch). There are maybe a dozen guns to choose from but some are noticeably better than others (stronger, more precise).  There’s even a rocket launcher on a few levels to take care of tanks/helicopters. An important distinction is that unlike the Max Payne games, you have a “regenerating health” system instead of a standard health bar. This means if you take damage, you just have to hide for a few seconds and you’ll fully recover. This of course means the game is faster paced and you’re going to be more likely to try daring Rambo style attacks or charge enemy positions.Pros:+I mentioned the gritty storyline, and I actually enjoyed it. The “hero” Kane makes all sorts of stupid but believable decisions, and his new partner Lynch is even dumber. There are no “good guys” in this game, as is probably the case among real world criminal thugs.+This is straightforward action, no puzzle solving or map exploring. You won’t get “lost” while playing this game, which I appreciate when I want to just blast my way through a mediocre game in one afternoon.Cons:-The game’s graphics are lackluster for something less than 10 years old, and the gameplay can be kind of clunky. I am told that if you have Windows 10, you will not be able to adequately run this game.-I mentioned blasting my way through the game in one afternoon, and by that I mean the game is like 5 hours long. Hope you got it for a cheap price because there really isn’t that much replay value.Overall, I don’t regret playing the game, but I’m glad I got it from a Humble Bundle because there’s nothing about it that’s “awesome.” Not horrible either though. 6.5/10

												Spectacularly inept and ill-considered attempt to make a gritty third person shooter. It clearly wanted to pay homage to Michael Mann's crime films and their tales of tortured antiheroes living on the edge, but the writing falls far short of the mark, producing flat caricatures who slaughter their way from one bungled job to the next, gunning down waves of rock-stupid AI enemies while grousing about their luck. The game's director said he was sick of goody two-shoes video game protagonists and wanted to do something different, but it feels like some pretty fundamental lessons of characterization and dialog were lost in translation. Even if you overlook the fatal flaws in the narrative, however, the gameplay is clunky, repetitive, and entirely linear, with swimmy controls and fitful feedback. Maybe it could be chalked up to age if not for the fact that I've played better third person shooters that came out years before this one - and they still hold up even a decade+ on. Skip it and try a Max Payne game instead.

												Violence in our video games is a pretty common thing nowadays, and while there is nothing wrong with that I don't think that the true extent of violence's effect on people is looked at very well. You can gun down a bunch of people in video games and it seems that it doesn't have too much effect on the story, with exceptions to Undertale and Dishonored. Our protagonists kill so many people that they, reasistically at least, are either sociopaths who don't care about murder or have therapy bills up to the roof. Games seem to ignore this aspect in the story, and if anything try to downplay it by showing that they're emotionally stable and act just like normal people even though they've killed more people than some wars have, even giving witty one-liners like in GTA. Ultimately, it's an ignorable aspect of these games, and competent writers do a good job with making these characters likable, but you almost never see a developer make a ♥♥♥♥ed up character who can't think straight because of the killing they've done. That's where Kane and Lynch: Dead Men comes in. Made by IO Interactive, the studio known for the Hitmen games, Kane and Lynch: Dead Men looks at this issue from a much more interesting angle. Does it do it well, though? Let's take a look.STORY: You're Kane, a former mercenary on death row for killing a bunch of people. However, when you're being transported to be killed, you and Lynch, a fellow inmate, are broken out by a mercenary group called The7. Unfortunately for Kane, The7 have beef with him for running away, leaving men to die and taking a bunch of cash. Kane is forced to get the money back, as they have his family held hostage and will kill them if he doesn't do it, with Lynch tagging along as help as well as someone to snitch to The7 if he ♥♥♥♥s up or tries to run. Things don't go as they should, and Kane and Lynch go after The7. The story is actually pretty solid despite some cliches, it provides a fresher twist on the story by putting it through the perspective of two guys who would be the villains in most other games and it feels like they put effort into it. It does jump around here and there, at one point they just robbed a bank in the US, then all of the sudden they're in a nightclub in Japan, but it could have been much worst in that regard and it's not too bad. There are two endings, both being kind of depressing, but are still solid and aren't horrendously sequel-baity. Sadly the game is pretty short, I finished it in about four hours, though to be fair, it feels like a complete story and, while some stuff here and there could be added, it feels about as long as it should be.GAMEPLAY: 3rd person shooter. You can carry one primary weapon, one sidearm, and a couple types of grenades around with you. If you're downed during combat, Lynch or another AI companion will hit you with some adreneline, but if you go down in a close timeframe from your last hit, you'll OD on it, which encourages you to stay in cover as much as you can. Unfortunately for the player, the cover system is broken at best and at worst barely functions, as you only seem to go into cover at the ends of things that you can take cover behind, which feels weird. Shooting feels too loose as well, and while it isn't as bad as cover, it's mostly mediocre. You can also command Lynch and your later companions in crime, but unfortunately the command system is kind of barebones and the AI can be pretty stupid. Moving around is fine enough at least, but for the most part, the gameplay is average. I wouldn't say it's unplayable like a decent amount of people say it is, in fact it's far from it, but it's nothing special and the game is held back by it.GRAPHICS, LEVEL DESIGN, AND PERFORMANCE: It's a game originally released on the Xbox 360 back in 2007, don't expect a pretty game. There are some bad looking textures even for 2007's standards, though it doesn't look terrible and some leeway has to be given to a game almost a decade old graphically. The performance is solid, I got a consistant 60FPS and if it ever dipped below that, I didn't notice it, and the cutscenes are pretty solid for that time. There are also a lot of cool levels, like a nightclub in Japan packed with people (who you can gun down if you want to), opium fields in Venezuela, and a fight in a construction yard which are nice to play around in.CHARACTERS AND VOICE ACTING: Let it be known that you probably will not like Kane and Lynch, as they are not good people and the game does not go out of its way to make you like them. Kane seems to know right from wrong and he does know that he should be dead, he's just alive so he can protect his daughter and take out The7, but he is a sociopath who kills people and doesn't seem to feel bad. Lynch seems like a better character initially, though it turns out he is a schitzophrenic who has phychotic episodes even if he does take his medication, snaps easily and kills people while blaming his schitzophrenia for it which might not be the full story to why it's happening. They also don't look like the traditional protagonists; they're older, balding, Kane's nose is broken and he has a ♥♥♥♥ed up scar, Lynch is overweight, they look and act like side villains in a video game. With that said, I did kind of end up liking Kane and Lynch, at least to some degree. They both know they're killers and nothing more, which is strangely refreshing to play as. The rest of the characters are mostly irredeemable or unlikable as well, which feels right for a band of killers. The voice acting is top notch as well, which lends to making the characters feel believable.MULTIPLAYER: There is co-op, though sadly online co-op is not possible, which is a real shame because it would be fun to play this with a friend. If you do play as Lynch during co-op, you get to see the psychotic episodes he goes through in the story through his eyes, which is a badass feature that they added which adds to the character. There is also an online mode which I did not bother with since I'd need to make a Games With Windows account and it's most likely dead anyway, though I hear it actually isn't that bad.FINAL THOUGHTS: The gameplay is mediocre and while that does hold it back, Kane and Lynch: Dead Men has enough going for it that I feel condifent in recommending it. 7/10, I might be a bit generous to the game, and at it's original $60 I can see it being not worth it, but for eight bucks while not on sale, it's a bargain. If you do want to wait for a sale, I can understand that, but do pick it up at some point, because Kane and Lynch: Dead Men is something really special, and I'm hoping that IO Interactive do something with the franchise in the future.

You just have to install the Xlive folder in the actual game.) But, where does one begin with Kane and Lynch? ... Probably with Kane and Lynch. They suck. They are the least-likeable a-holes I've met in a game. And I'm supposed to connect with them, according to the game. Look! Whenever Kane get's shot down he thinks about people yelling at him. I'd rather call him a wuss than an empathetic character. I started to like Lynch for his dark comedic moments, but as the game went on, he just turned into this hate-spewing jerk that would ruin a lot of missions and cause them to go on far longer than they'd have to (In the actual script). He also ruins a lot of tries I've had at levels, because the AI is so off in this game. Enemies are not only really dumb, but the "tactical" system of the gameplay turns into babysitting, since most of my squadmates wanted to go out and shake hands with the enemy. And if an ally is shot down, they're on a timer for you personally to heal them. I never found out an alternative to have my other allies heal them, but no. I'd have to run in the middle of enemy fire in the next 15 seconds or I fail the mission. Also the cover-shooting sucks horribly in this game. The game is incredibly picky about where you take cover, and even when you successfully take cover, most of the time enemies will shoot through your cover. I had a helecopter shoot through solid concrete and kill me. Solid concrete. If you can't take cover behind something that'd make sense to take cover behind (like bales of hay or low walls that just can't be used for cover, because it hurts their feelings) you could always duck behind them... after Kane hesitates a few moments to get his head shot. The whole time, I kept thinking about much better games I could be playing like Grand Theft Auto, Uncharted, or Mass Effect with much better characters and mechanics.Oh! And what's the biggest problem in the game? The story. It's a floppy, predictable mess. The places you go to have very loose connections and you can end up in the middle of Cuba dressed as a guerilla in the middle of a firefight with no explanation of how you got there, other than, "We need to get so-and-so." And all the characters besides Kane and Lynch involved in the story are just as unlikeable or just flat-out forgettable. The game tries to make me feel all emotional when bad things happen to Kane's family, but I had no reason to care for them OR him. In fact, I personally think that the more horrible things happened to Kane and Lynch, the better. They really deserve it. I like Niko Bellic, Tommy Vercetti, and Trevor- because they have redeeming qualities.... Well, maybe not Trevor, but still. Kane and Lynch have no redeeming qualities. They're just heartless jerks that kill tons of people. K&L also wanted to go with the choice-influenced ending, where you choose to stick with your mates and tough it out or go with the coward's ending. After playing this muddy game for so long, I didn't really care about the moral implications of my choice or the "good" or "bad" ending coming about. I chose the one that ended the game faster. Yeah, I'm a coward. Deal with it.This is a horrible game. The characters, story, and gameplay are all over the place and poorly put-together. Do yourself a favor and buy a Grand Theft Auto game. It's got better elements in all three of the categories, and you can feel like the a-hole for killing tons of people in it- not hate the characters for being a-holes.

												This was a surprisingly good game. It's not great by any means, but if you can be forgiving of its shortcomings, the plot will reward you.PROS+ Excellent story. The setup drags a little bit, but once you're into the meat of things, it keeps you hooked.+ A solid script, characters who are less heroic than your average shooter, and nice voice-acting add a lot of gravitas.+ There are some truly great setpieces worth experiencing, namely a shootout in a crowded nightclub and a moving daylight shootout through the streets of Tokyo. They're reminiscent of Michael Mann movies like Collateral and Heat.+ The squad commands allow you to employ some complex tactics in firefights, advancing under covering fire, guarding each other's flanks, etc.+ Some inspired moments of art direction.CONS- The weakest levels and least polish - including an atrocious driving level - are all up front, meaning that if you bounce off the game you'll bounce off hard.- The A.I. isn't terrible, but the things that it does well - flanking and maneuvers - are limited by linear level design that doesn't cater to it and exposes its weaknesses.- The cover system is inconsistent. You'll abandon it pretty quickly, not that it makes a huge difference in the gameplay.- Lack of polish abounds. Jagged edges, texture bugging on an early level, some too-simple level design.- Games for Windows. We all know why.PRO OR CON???There are some nasty difficulty spikes, even on Easy mode. It takes some trial and error. Normally, that kind of unevenness wears thin very quickly for me, but something about the story kept me going at it anyway.This is a SOFT RECOMMENDATION. It's not a big money risk, given its sale prices now, and you can finish it in a few evenings max, so it's not a big time sink either. Story's worth it, and a few moments are very memorable.

												Kane and Lynch: Dead Men™, made by the developers of critically acclaimed action shooter series "Hitman" comes back with a bit more slowly paced, tactical-focused game. Nah muh níggas I'm just playin witchu.Kane and Lynch is indeed made by the same guys who made Hitman series (they even let you know of that in the intro). One day, someone thought "Guys, we be makin dem stealth games but what if... a shooter?" and so the Kane and Lynch happened.  DER PLOT Kane (the protagonist) is an ex-mercenary. We meet him in a prison van that is taking him to (hehe what a plot twist) the prison where he will get fried for being a baddie hired gun. His thoughts revolve around his wife and daughter, both of which he abandoned and now he regrets it (good timing, bro). In the same van we meet Lynch, pretty much a psycho who killed his wife during one of his "blackouts" as he calls them.Then suddenly BAM BOOM KAPOW RATATA SOME MASKED GUYS ATTACK THE CONVOY AND GRAB KANE AND LYNCH WITH THEM AND OH GOD EVERYONE SHOOTS EVERYONE, COPS DROP LIKE FLIES, WHAT A FUKKEN CHAOS, JESUS CHRIST ALMIGHTY. Turns out that they were hired by some super top secret criminal organisation which Kane stole loadsamoney from in the past and now they make him get the money back. Lynch is freed because Kane needs a sidekick and who would make a better sidekick than a psychopath?Long story short: they set on an adventure to retrieve the money for the crime syndicate, making friends and enemies on their way. However, Kane faces a personal tragedy by the hands of the criminal people and that makes him upset enough to actually shift his focus on killing them instead of killing cops, Japs, and Jap cops as he did by that point. He then goes to South America and whoops their criminal a$$es. Lynch is with him all the time and he fuks shít up because he's a psycho.Kane and Lynch then shoot the criminal men. The end. DER GAMEPLAY If you ever played any Hitman game I think you can agree that shooting wasn't really the strong point of the series. It didn't matter, Hitman is about stealth anyway. Here however their lack of experience shows (well in 2003 they made this shooter called Freedom Fighters, it was rather good, you can look it up). It's not bad, aight? Not very good but not bad either. I had a feeling like weapons don't generally deal much damage and are very inaccurate. When you get downed one of your mates can inject one marijuana into your eyeball to revive you, but once he does that, you cannot get revived for again some time because otherwise you overdose and die. Sounds fun and all but when you get injected and then get shot down quickly afterwards, instead of immidiately dying, you have to wait for a guy to come to give you another marijuana shot which kills you. WHY CAN'T I IMMIDIATELY DIE INSTEAD?!?!?!?! This works both ways. Sometimes your mates get knocked out too and you have to give them the medical weed, otherwise they die and it's game over. You can give your men simple commands like "stay here", "follow me", "go there", "attack that nígga", etc. I generally didn't use them but sometimes they came in handy. DER CONCLUSION Kane and Lynch: Dead Men™ is not the best game I have ever played. It is above average, I'd say. However, despite some very questionable design choices both gameplay and plot wise, I enjoyed this title. The game looks pretty ok to me even today. The story reminds me the action movies starring Bruce Willis or some shít like that. It was really neat.6,7/10 on my scale. If it's on sale or something, definitely worth picking it up. Also has co-op mode but didn't try it.

												So during a sale I bought a lot of things for my friends and a few things for myself. Two of the things I got for myself were from the recommendation of another. I had just finished Spec Ops: The Line and wanted another TPS, and a friend said I should get Kane and Lynch 1 and 2 (they were both four dollars).When these games came out, they weren't negatively received or anything - they just were received as pretty much average, and therefore they faded into obscurity, basically. A lot of people don't like them. Having played the first one in full and some of the second one, I'm not surprised that in this world where a lot of people like things such as Skyrim this is the case.The game develops the two main characters really, really well. You get a sense of who they are and what they are trying to do moreso than other games. There's little subtle things like hearing events of Kane's life in the past when you're on the ground about to possibly die, hearing mortally wounded police on the ground quietly breathe and beg to be spared, saying things like "please...I have a family", the fact that a lot of the NPCs that fight by your side lack any sort of empathy whatsoever, and most prominently, Lynch speaking to himself constantly throughout the game, with his psychotic tendencies very apparent. There's actually a scene where he ends up executing a bunch of hostages that need to be kept alive. I didn't know until just recently that if you play co-op, the person controlling Lynch actually lives out these events and hallucinates the hostages as being SWAT members. The ultimate irony is that all these sort of things on an individual level are more human of moments than Spec Ops is collectively with pretty much it's entire story - when that's a game that is supposed to be completely about that sort of thing. By the end of the game, the story I'd played felt very true and structured - not common in shooters. Why these games got 6 and 7 out of 10s is beyond me.

												Summary: Short, uninspired, buggy.Kane & Lynch as an idea has all the elements that make Hitman, developed also by IO, work. A contracted killer, here a mercenary that worked as part of a group rather than a lone hitman, bound for death row, gets out of prison by his old group to make amends. His family is kidnapped and he has to comply to save them. Although a bit cliche, the story could work, but it simply doesn't. The characters are underdeveloped, the plot never gets deeper, while large gaps are left to fill in with your imagination.Gameplay-wise, the gunplay isn't anything to write home about, reminding of linear FPS that were considered outdated even by 2007 standards, with bullet-sponge enemies. The guns are often inaccurate, even in short distances and while firing with discipline (aiming, short bursts etc.). The cover system doesn't always work and sometimes while you are in cover you still get shot without the situation justifying it (e.g. when covering behind solid rock or cement that shouldn't be pierced by bullets. The AI is laughable, with some covering the wrong way opening themselves to shots, or when in groups just running straight at you, which diminishes any sense that you are fighting actual opponents. The game requires Games for Windows Live, and in newer systems you have to find out on your own and download the client yourself in order for the game to launch. Multiplayer is long-dead, co-op is off-line only, the campaign is short (I finished it in ~6 hours while really taking my time). There's also a few crashes and glitches, although this is an afterthought in the game which is already dissapointing.I got this as part of a bundle and it was as good as a movie you let play in the background. You can skip it safely and not miss anything, if you really want to play the second one (haven't played that yet, so no idea if it any good), just read the plot online, you're not missing anything.

												Kane & Lynch: Dead Men is a third person shooter game with a few interesting twists, but ultimately the poor execution of some elements drag it down quite a bit.First off I've played this game a bit when it came out on Xbox, did a little bit of coop back then, but never finished it. It has been sitting in my Steam library for a while now until I recently decided to finish it. The game itself was released in a time where things were still good in the gaming business and companies churned out games at a fast pace. It was also a high time for Xbox and most relevantly coop was the thing every game needed to have.STORYThe game takes an interesting perspective from the bad guy who gets broken out of prison and is confronted with his past. Needless to say life as a mercenary is shady and he did some things his former employers couldn't agree with. His wife and daughter are leveraged and he is blackmailed into retrieving something. Beyond that the story gets rather predictive with failure and revenge as central pivoting points.GAMEPLAYAs said the game is a third person shooter and the controls handle a bit slow and rough, but when playing with the controller everything runs pretty good. Cover mechanics however are poorly done and for some reason you can only get in cover on the edge of a wall, even the lower ones. This is very frustrating since enemies are abundant and aim pretty good, even on the lowest difficulty. On the other hand most of your weapons have such low accuracy you really have to get very close to hit something. Result is that moving from cover to cover gets you killed most of the time, luckily your team-mates revive you almost every time.And that is pretty much the only thing they get right, other than that they're pretty useless. You have a few basic commands, but anything other than 'Stay here' or 'Come over' is pointless. You can order them to attack a specific target, but this just results in them rushing towards it and shooting them in the face with a shotgun. The animation however is pretty nice though. That's mostly the gameplay throughout the game, aside from a few vehicle missions.VISUALSThe game is a bit older, but it still looks acceptable, but nothing special. There is some destructibility, which was also very popular back then. Most animations in the game appear somewhat crude, but then again acceptable for it's age. It should run pretty good on today's laptops as a counter argument.AUDIOThe audio is nothing to be noted specifically, no orchestral scores. Just your standard background music with a few tension increasing tempos. The voice acting, including lip sync, is actually pretty good for the standard of those days. But the dialogs happen mostly during game, which can be very incomprehensible at times. However most of them are restricted to a lot of swearing and banter, so you won't miss much.MULTIPLAYERAs said the game can be played coop and it will be waaaay more fun when playing with some buddies, like with much of these coop games. Also the online versus mode is very original, especially with a name like Fragile Alliance, things can get interesting. You can view the tutorial and get an impression of what it would be like, but that's about it. Servers are dead, both coop and versus. So sadly I cannot divulge into this any further, but I can expect it would change my opinion of the game.VERDICTBuy it cheap if you want to experience the beginning of the franchise, but other than that just skip it and go straight to the next one. If you have enough friends who are willing to play it with you I would probably recommend this one for sure. Most coop games from previous generation are well worth it just for that.

												The game is like a 5/10 overall. Very short (on easy). Story feels like it has been bent to fit the levels rather than the other way around which isn't necessarily a bad thing... but the game is all over the place location wise. The first ~60% feels like your typical crime/mobster type of hollywood affair. [Location/mission spoilers]You've got your prison breaks, bank robberies, Heat rip-off and Nightclub scene.And then you fly to Cuba to assist in the liberation of Havana and follow it up with a set of jungle based guerilla warfare type missions. It feels like they took the alpha for Kane and Lynch and then glued it to some alpha concepts for a Freedom Fighters 2. And I say alpha because really the gameplay lets it down, not the mission concepts themselves. The cover system just doesn't seem to work, shooting feels meh, the squad/command system felt tacked on and so on. There is some cool tech behind it though - plenty of the missions are packed with enemies and civilians to make the world feel more real (and I assume this got used on the later Hitman). The characters themselves *could* have become something noteworthy in a Trevor/Michael GTAV sort of way, but they never really seem to go far with either of them. So yeah, it feels like the alpha of something that may have been great.

												If I could, I would give this game a "sideways thumb".Kane and Lynch is an odd game. For every good idea it has, there is an equally bad idea to balance it out. As the title suggests, the game is about Kane and Lynch, two mercenaries trying to get revenge on a mercenary group they used to work for. This plays out in typical third-person shooter fashion, with genre standards like cover system, squad mates, etc.The gameplay is a mixed bag. The guns themselves feel and sound punchy when they hit what you're aiming at, but all of them are almost comically short ranged, making for an odd combat dynamic. It's not particularly bad, mind you, but it did feel like I was running out into the open more often than what was sensible. Speaking of running out into the open, this game's cover system is completely broken. You're sort of supposed to push yourself up against whatever you want to duck behind, but I can count the number of times that actually worked right on two fingers. It's easier to just stand or crouch behind whatever you're trying to hide behind than to mess with this game's broken attempt at cover. The game also has some weird design choices, for example, the tutorial is actually in the second level, after you've spent an entire level shooting your way through enemies. The problem is, that first level doesn't give you any kind of instruction on what button to press when it wants you to do things like go into cover or climb onto something, so for that level, you're constantly checking the options menu to find out what button you're supposed to press, only to have the game try and teach you after you spent all that time trying to figure things out on your own. The one thing this game does to genuinely well is the squad system. It's fairly standard, you tell teammates where to guard, what to shoot, whether to hang back, but it's useful and works well. I also have to commend the game's inclusion of split-screen co-op. I haven't played this mode myself, but it's fairly rare to see split-screen on a PC shooter, so I respect its inclusion. Overall, the gameplay is odd, and broken in places, but it's playable and even has bursts of "hey, this is cool"The graphics are another example of how this game is all over the place. It came out in 2007, so looking a bit dated is excusable, but this looks like it got trapped in a sort of awkward tranitionary period between PS2 era graphics and Xbox 360-era graphics, something more akin to a game from 2004. Other games from 2007, such as Call of Duty 4 and The Orange Box were much more consistent and generally looked a lot better than this game does. The characters themselves look decent, except when beards (which look terrible in this game) are involved, featuring reasonably modern graphics techniques such as normal maps and whatnot (basically, the old wrinkly people you play as look old and wrinkly), but props and environments (including weapons), look like something from a PS2-era game, blocky and angular, with basic, low-resolution textures. Outdoor environments actually look fairly decent, being reasonably large and detailed, with good use of color and decent lighting, but indoor areas have a barren, almost abandoned feeling. This would be fine if you were supposed to be going through abandoned areas, but this game sends you through heavily populated areas such as banks and nightclubs, making these segments of the game feel odd and empty, and failing to convince me that I'm moving through and actual world. The buildings feel like they were just constructed and no one moved in yet, devoid of many of the props you would see in other games. One cool graphical thing this game does have going for it is that it features absolutely massive crowds. There are tons of people in places like the aforementioned nightclub, and they move out of your way and react in a surprisingly convincing way.Finally, let's talk about the storyline. I just could not care about this story or any of the people in it. It's cool that you get to play as an unambiguously bad set of characters, but the storytelling is poorly executed. Basically the group of assassins Kane and Lynch worked is trying to get back the money they think Kane took. When Kane fails to get the cash, they do a bad thing (I won't spoil what on the off chance someone actually cares), so Kane and Lynch try to get their revenge. It's an interesting setup, but none of the characters are ever fleshed out enough to make me want to care. The past relationship between Kane and the group isn't explained much, so their rivalry fails to be interesting, and neither Kane nor Lynch are interesting enough for me tor really latch on to either. You can have an interesting story about a complete amoral character (The recent film, "Nightcrawler" is an excellent example), but that's not the case here. Every character is kind of an idiot, and the worsening of their problems is always their own fault, making them more annoying than cool. You eventually pick up three side characters who serve as your "squad", and while their gameplay function is interesting, they serve almost no purpose to the story, and are basically nothing more than names. Their relation to Kane and Lynch is never explained and other than one or two offhand lines, they get no characterization other than "unpleasant". The game wants to be a Michael Mann crime revenge story, but has neither the style nor charm to do so.Overall, it's not a terrible game, but it's not particularly great either. It's certainly not worth the $7 price being asked, but if you can get it for $1.25 (which it drops to frequently), it's not the worst thing you could play. The game lasts about 6 hours, so it's okay as a "weekend game" that you can beat and forget about.[Note: I've previously posted this review on Amazon]
